title: 5 Things To Know: June 18, 2025
content: Right, five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. Israel and Iran trading air strikes for the sixth straight day. Current and former Trump administration officials tell NBC News that the president is considering a range of options including a possible US strike on Iran. Amazon's chief executive Andy Jassy says that the company's corporate workforce will shrink in the coming years as Amazon adapts adopts more generative AI tools and agents. In a memo to employees, Jassy said we will need fewer people doing some of the jobs that are being done today and more people doing other types of jobs. New York City Democratic Mayoral candidate Brad Lander has been released from custody after he was arrested by federal agents at an immigration court in Manhattan. summary:
The transcript covers several significant developments across geopolitics, corporate strategy, and US domestic policy. Internationally, Israel and Iran have been exchanging air strikes for the sixth consecutive day. This ongoing conflict has prompted discussions within current and former Trump administration circles about potential US responses, including the possibility of a direct US strike on Iran, signaling escalating tensions in the Middle East.

Domestically, Amazon's CEO, Andy Jassy, announced that the company's corporate workforce is projected to shrink in the coming years. This reduction is attributed to Amazon's increasing adoption of generative AI tools and agents, which Jassy noted would lead to fewer people being needed for certain roles and more for others. In New York City politics, Democratic Mayoral candidate Brad Lander gained public attention after being arrested by federal agents at an immigration court in Manhattan. Lander had reportedly linked arms with an individual authorities were attempting to detain, and his wife publicized the incident on X, suggesting the arrest might boost his campaign.

On the legislative front, the US Senate successfully passed the 'Genius Act,' a bill designed to regulate US dollar-pegged stable coins, with a notable bipartisan vote of 68 to 30. Attention now shifts to the House, which is actively working on its own stable coin legislation, indicating a concerted effort towards digital currency regulation. Concurrently, the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released a report projecting that former President Trump's package of tax cuts would increase federal deficits by $2.8 trillion over the next decade, even after accounting for other economic effects. This CBO finding counters the argument from Congressional Republicans that tax cuts would sufficiently spur economic growth to offset any governmental revenue losses.

key_points.text: The broadcast highlights five key things to know before today's opening bell.
Israel and Iran have been trading air strikes for six straight days.
Current and former Trump administration officials informed NBC News of potential US response options.
A possible US strike on Iran is among the options being considered by the president.
Amazon's CEO, Andy Jassy, announced that the company's corporate workforce will shrink in the coming years.
The reduction in Amazon's workforce is due to the adoption of more generative AI tools and agents.
Jassy stated in an employee memo that fewer people will be needed for some jobs, while more will be needed for others.
New York City Democratic Mayoral candidate Brad Lander was released from custody.
Brad Lander was arrested by federal agents at an immigration court in Manhattan.
Lander had linked arms with a person authorities were attempting to detain.
Lander's wife posted about his arrest on X (formerly Twitter).
Lander, in his role as New York City controller, was escorting a defendant out of court.
It is suggested that Lander's arrest could provide a boost to his campaign.
There's a mention of another 'young guy' mayoral candidate described as 'radical' and 'communist'.
This 'radical' candidate advocates for defunding the police.
AOC (Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez) endorsed the 'radical' mayoral candidate.
Brad Lander appeared on CNN last night.
Lander received a call from a CNN booker immediately after his arrest video.
The video of Lander's arrest was considered beneficial for him.
The speaker suggests that similar arrests for publicity are a growing trend among politicians.
Lander was reportedly right next to Governor Kathy Hochul of New York during the incident.
The Senate passed a bill to regulate US dollar-pegged stable coins, known as the Genius Act.
The Senate vote on the stable coin bill was 68 to 30.
The stable coin bill passed the Senate with bipartisan support.
Attention now shifts to the House, which is developing its own stable coin bill.
The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) reported on President Trump's tax cuts.
The CBO stated Trump's package of tax cuts would increase deficits by $2.8 trillion over the next decade.
The CBO's deficit projection includes other economic effects.
Congressional Republicans argue that tax cuts would spur economic growth.
Republicans believe economic growth from tax cuts would offset any government revenue loss.
The stable coin legislation includes provisions for auditing these assets.
It is suggested that the stable coin initiative is a good idea and will work.
Some individuals believe stable coins could actually boost the US dollar.
The idea that stable coins boost the US dollar is linked to the need for liquid assets.
